description.summary: A legendary serpent with a rooster's head from medieval European folklore. Known for its deadly petrifying gaze, poisonous breath, and birth from a rooster's egg incubated by a serpent or toad.
description.full: The cockatrice is a mythical creature from medieval European folklore, depicted as a two-legged dragon or serpent with a rooster's head and wings. Often conflated with the basilisk, the cockatrice is sometimes distinguished by having wings while the basilisk does not. Born from a yolkless egg laid by a rooster and incubated by a serpent or toad, the cockatrice possesses lethal powers including a petrifying gaze, poisonous breath, and deadly touch. Its weaknesses include weasels, its own reflection in a mirror, and the crow of a rooster. The creature features prominently in medieval bestiaries, heraldry, and literature.

etymology.origin: From Middle English 'cocatris', from Old French 'cocatris', from Late Latin 'calcatrix' (tracker), influenced by 'coccus' (berry) and later associated with 'cock' (rooster).

size.description: Small to medium, typically depicted as chicken-sized to large dog-sized

features.description: Head of a rooster with comb and wattles
Long serpentine or dragon tail, sometimes barbed
Typically depicted with two legs rather than four

physical.morphology: Bipedal creature combining rooster head and wings with serpent or dragon body and tail

abilities.description: Gaze that can turn victims to stone or kill instantly
Breath so toxic it withers plants and poisons the air
Touch that can kill on contact
Ability to fly with dragon or bird wings

cultural_presence.notes: Featured in illuminated manuscripts and natural history texts

cultural_presence.name: Heraldry
cultural_presence.notes: Used as heraldic symbol representing deadly vigilance

cultural_presence.name: Literature
cultural_presence.notes: Appears in Spenser's 'Faerie Queene' and other works

origins.cultural_roots: Medieval European folklore, possibly influenced by Classical basilisk legends and fear of roosters laying eggs (a rare medical condition).
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to basilisk mythology, dragon lore, and medieval natural history beliefs

timeline.significance: Cockatrice becomes established in medieval bestiary tradition
Notable literary appearance in major English epic poem
Streets and alleys named 'Cock Lane' as warnings of cockatrice sightings

history.modern_era: The cockatrice remains a popular creature in heraldry, fantasy literature, and gaming. It appears in works like Harry Potter and various role-playing games, maintaining its status as a classic medieval monster.

birth_myth.description: Born from a yolkless egg (sometimes called a 'cock's egg') laid by a seven-year-old rooster and incubated by a serpent or toad on a dunghill
variations: Hatched during the dog days of summer

weaknesses.description: The weasel is immune to the cockatrice's gaze and is its natural enemy
Its own reflection can petrify or kill it
The sound of a rooster crowing is fatal to the cockatrice

historical.description: Medieval bestiaries with cockatrice illustrations and descriptions
Cockatrice symbols in coat of arms and heraldic devices

literary.author: Edmund Spenser
literary.description: Notable appearance in English epic poetry

folkloric.name: Rooster egg phenomenon
